title: Bowling Vocabulary
description: Roll into this quiz about the language of bowling!

questions.question: In bowling, what is a 'turkey'?
options: Knocking down only one pin
Three consecutive strikes
A split where no pins are touching
A gutter ball
questions.explanation: A turkey in bowling is three consecutive strikes in a single game, one of the sport's most satisfying achievements.

questions.question: In bowling, what is a 'split'?
options: Bowling with two hands
The division between frames
A spare where remaining pins have a gap between them
Dividing the score between two players
questions.explanation: A split occurs when the first ball of a frame leaves two or more non-adjacent groups of pins standing, with a gap between them, making a spare very difficult.

questions.question: What is the 'pocket' in bowling?
options: The gutter on either side of the lane
The ideal entry point between the 1 and 3 pins (for right-handers)
The finger holes in the ball
Where you keep your bowling ball
questions.explanation: The pocket is the ideal target area for a strike, located between the 1 and 3 pins for right-handed bowlers (1 and 2 for left-handers).

questions.question: In bowling, what does a 'gutter ball' mean?
options: A ball that rolls into the gutter channel without hitting any pins
A ball that bounces off the lane
A ball thrown too slowly
A ball that hits only the gutter-side pins
questions.explanation: A gutter ball rolls off the lane surface into one of the gutters (channels) running along each side, scoring zero pins for that delivery.

questions.question: What is a 'perfect game' in bowling?
options: Scoring 300 by bowling 12 consecutive strikes
Converting every spare in a game
Winning by the largest margin
Never throwing a gutter ball
questions.explanation: A perfect game in bowling is a score of 300, achieved by rolling 12 consecutive strikes (one in each of the ten frames, plus two bonus strikes in the tenth).

questions.question: In bowling, what is the '7-10 split'?
options: Alternating between 7 and 10 pin knockdowns
Bowling in the 7th and 10th frames
Only the 7 and 10 pins remaining, the hardest split to convert
A score of 7 in the 10th frame
questions.explanation: The 7-10 split leaves only the far-left (7) and far-right (10) pins standing, widely considered the most difficult spare to convert in bowling.

questions.question: What does 'hook' refer to in bowling?
options: The curved end of a bowling pin
Hanging the ball over the gutter
A penalty for crossing the foul line
A ball that curves as it travels down the lane
questions.explanation: A hook is a bowling delivery where the ball curves across the lane as it approaches the pins, created by the bowler's release and the ball's rotation.

questions.question: In bowling, what is the 'approach'?
options: The strategy for picking up a spare
The area behind the foul line where bowlers take their steps before releasing the ball
The angle at which the ball hits the pins
Walking up to the lane counter
questions.explanation: The approach is the area of the lane behind the foul line where bowlers take their steps and build momentum before releasing the ball.

questions.question: What is a 'spare' in bowling?
options: Having no pins left after the first ball
A backup bowling ball
Knocking down all remaining pins with the second ball of a frame
An extra ball at the end of the game
questions.explanation: A spare is achieved when a bowler knocks down all remaining pins with the second ball of a frame, after failing to strike with the first.

questions.question: In bowling, what does 'Brooklyn' mean?
options: A gutter ball that curves back onto the lane
A strike hit on the wrong side of the headpin
A bowling style from New York
A perfect game bowled left-handed
questions.explanation: A Brooklyn strike occurs when the ball hits the opposite side of the headpin from the intended pocket -- the 1-2 pocket for a right-hander instead of the 1-3.

questions.question: What is the 'foul line' in bowling?
options: The boundary line between lanes
A line showing where the pins are set up
A line drawn where smelly shoes are not allowed
The line at the end of the approach that bowlers must not cross
questions.explanation: The foul line is the boundary at the end of the approach area. Crossing it with any part of the body during delivery results in a foul and a score of zero for that ball.

questions.question: In bowling, what is a 'kingpin'?
options: The tournament champion
The head pin at the front
The heaviest pin in the set
The number 5 pin in the center of the pin arrangement
questions.explanation: The kingpin is the number 5 pin, located in the center of the pin triangle. In some bowling terminology, it refers to the most important pin for achieving strikes.

questions.question: What is 'lane oil' (or 'lane dressing') in bowling?
options: Oil applied to the lane surface that affects ball movement
A polish for the bowling pins
A lubricant for bowling ball finger holes
A cleaning product for bowling shoes
questions.explanation: Lane oil is a conditioner applied to the wooden or synthetic lane surface in specific patterns, which protects the lane and significantly affects how bowling balls react and curve.

questions.question: In bowling, what does 'sandbagging' mean?
options: Deliberately bowling below your ability to maintain a lower average
Adding weight to your bowling shoes
Using a heavy ball
Filling gutters with sand
questions.explanation: Sandbagging is the practice of intentionally bowling below one's true ability to maintain an artificially low average, gaining an advantage in handicap competitions.

questions.question: What are 'bumpers' in bowling?
options: Protective guards on bowling pins
Padding on the lane walls
Retractable rails that block the gutters, often used by beginners
Cushions on the ball return
questions.explanation: Bumpers are retractable guardrails that can be raised in the gutters to prevent gutter balls, commonly used for children and beginners to keep the ball on the lane.
